intro: Calceolaria ascendens var. subincisa, commonly known as the ascending slipper orchid, is a flowering plant native to the Andean regions of South America. It belongs to the family Campanulaceae and is characterized by its unique, slipper-shaped flowers that are often brightly colored. The plant typically grows in high-altitude environments, thriving in cool, moist climates with well-drained soil. Its leaves are usually lance-shaped and covered in fine hairs, while the stems are erect and often branched. This variety is prized for its ornamental value and is cultivated in gardens for its striking floral display.
